user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_NewNode:
```c
UtListNode_t *UtList_NewNode(void *Data, uint32 DataSize)
{
    union NodeAllocator
    {
        UtListNode_t Node;
        double       AlignDbl;
        void *       AlignPtr;
        long         AlignLong;
    } * AllocNode;

    AllocNode = malloc(sizeof(union NodeAllocator) + DataSize);
    memset(AllocNode, 0, sizeof(union NodeAllocator));
    AllocNode->Node.Data     = &AllocNode[1];
    AllocNode->Node.DataSize = DataSize;
    memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize);

    AllocNode->Node.Next = &AllocNode->Node;
    AllocNode->Node.Prev = &AllocNode->Node;

    return &AllocNode->Node;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtList_NewNode:
void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
{
    UtListNode_t *TagHead;
    UtListNode_t *NewNode;

    TagHead = UtList_GetHead(ListHead, Tag);
    if (TagHead != NULL)
    {
        NewNode      = UtList_NewNode(Data, DataSize);
        NewNode->Tag = Tag;
        UtList_Insert_Before(TagHead, NewNode);
    }
}
...
UtListNode_t *UtList_GetHead(UtListHead_t *ListHead, uint32 Tag)
{
    if (Tag >= ListHead->NumberOfTags)
    {
        return NULL;
    }
    return &ListHead->Tags[Tag];
}
...
void UtList_Insert_Before(UtListNode_t *ExistingNode, UtListNode_t *NewNode)
{
    NewNode->Next       = ExistingNode;
    NewNode->Prev       = ExistingNode->Prev;
    NewNode->Prev->Next = NewNode;
    NewNode->Next->Prev = NewNode;
}
...
void UtTest_AddCommon(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *TestName,
                      uint32 EntryType)
{
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    memset(&UtTestDataBaseEntry, 0, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry));
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Test     = Test;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Setup    = Setup;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Teardown = Teardown;
    if (TestName != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName, TestName, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName) - 1);
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Add(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, &UtTestDataBaseEntry, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry_t), EntryType);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided functions and their call relationships. The call graph from the supplied code is: UtTest_AddCommon -> UtList_Add -> {UtList_GetHead, UtList_NewNode, UtList_Insert_Before}. UtList_NewNode only calls standard library functions (malloc, memset, memcpy) and does not invoke any of the other project functions. UtList_GetHead and UtList_Insert_Before have no calls to other project functions. None of the shown functions call themselves directly, and there is no mutual (indirect) calling cycle among the provided functions. The standard library functions used do not call back into these project functions. The function-pointer fields stored in data (Test, Setup, Teardown) are only copied into the new list node and are not invoked here, so they do not introduce recursion in the shown code. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied snippets that need further investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 (no direct or indirect recursion). If additional, not-provided functions exist elsewhere that are called by any of these routines (or if any of the omitted type definitions contain hooks that call back into these functions), those should be inspected; but based solely on the provided code, no suspicious fragments were found.
